psychological_feature.bdy:
Police sketch of the Unabomber by
Jeanne Boylan
. The Unabomber (later identified as
Theodore Kaczynski
), was an unofficial and involuntary candidate to be 43rd
President of the United States .
Unabomber for President was a political campaign with the overt aim of electing
"The Unabomber"
as a write-in candidate in the
United States presidential election, 1996 .1 The campaign's slogan was "
if elected, he will not serve
."
The campaign was launched in
Boston in September 1995 by Lydia Eccles – a Boston artist who had long harbored concerns about "totalitarian tendencies in technology" – and antinatalist
Chris Korda . It took the overt form of a political action committee, Unabomber Political Action Committee (UNAPACK).2 Influenced initially by ideas of the
Situationist International , the group included anarchists, hard-core punk rockers, '60s types, eco-leftists, pacifists, militants and primitivists.1 Its supporters included decentralized anarchist collective
CrimethInc. and the
Church of Euthanasia
.3
The campaign received national publicity, and attempts by news organizations to portray it as frivolous were resisted by UNAPACK, who insisted that the issues raised by Kaczynski were portentous, concerning "the fate of mankind".1 In the words of the
Phoenix New Times , the campaign was "an effort designed to cast votes in protest of the existing hierarchy and its potential replacement."4 The Maoist Internationalist Movement criticized the campaign as typifying " life-style politics anarchism" and as encouraging protest votes instead of seizing political power from the bourgeoisie.5
As Bill Brown, director of the campaign's
New York
office, said at the time "most of the media are unable to deal with the campaign…[t]here is no way for people to understand why you would say 'Unabomber for President' and that gives us a tactical opportunity to explain ourselves."6 The intended symbolism of the campaign was not that it was a joke, but that the political system was a joke.6
The campaign won
Reason magazine's best bumper sticker for their effort "FED UP WITH 'PROGRESS'? Write-in UNABOMBER For PRESIDENT '96."7

Phoenix New Times . Retrieved on 2008-04-07.

Brown, Bill. Interview with Joey Manley. Interview with Unabomer for President Political Action Committee NYC. New York City. 1996. Retrieved on 2008-04-14.

Reason . Retrieved on 2008-04-08.
